reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Hero of the Kingdom
Original Release: 2012
Genre Tags: RPG; Point & Click; Casual; Adventure
My Overall Grade: B
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 4-6 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Casual gamers
REVIEWHero of the Kingdom is an interesting thing.  The game style blends elements of point-and-click adventure games, resource management/economy games, and role-playing games.  It is extremely casual (I don‚Äôt even think you can lose) and relaxing, but also is rewarding.  I can see how some people may find it monotonous, but I personally found it addictive and gratifying.

First and foremost, I want to underline the casual and simplistic nature of this game.  I can appreciate an epic, immersive, huge-budget AAA title as much as the next guy; but I also really enjoy casual games for those moments when I want to get my Zen on and play something ‚Äúlite.‚Äù  This game is great for that kind of situation‚Ä¶ but if you are someone who prefers the AAA epics, Hero of the Kingdom likely won‚Äôt tickle your fancy.

The game plays as a point-and-click adventure, essentially‚Äî with an inventory and a narrative.  In order to progress (i.e.: complete quests) you must pass inventory checks that determine if you have enough of specific items.  Thus, playing the game boils down to growing your inventory in two ways.  By finding camouflaged objects on the screen and clicking on them.  And by bartering with the NPCs; there are numerous profitable NPC-trading loops that can be used to make money and buy inventory items you need.

The narrative is extremely light; there are very few total lines of text.  While it isn‚Äôt bad, it also is easily forgettable.  But it does a good enough job creating a feeling of advancement and incentive as you complete quests.  There are also a lot of well-spaced achievements (both in game and on Steam) that pop-up often to keep the game feeling rewarding as you progress through the campaign.

For those who seek more intense gaming experiences, you may find this game somewhat tedious.  However, if you like tranquil, addictive games that are rewarding, there is a good chance you will enjoy Hero of the Kingdom.

reviewText:
Do you like clicking? No, do you derive intense pleasure from pressing a mouse button and watching numbers go up, for the sake of then being able to click a few more things and have those same numbers go up even faster?

Hero of the Kingdom in almost every respect is a cleverly disguised iteration on the bizarrely addictive idle games that have been devouring souls since it was discovered people on the internet will do absolutely anything to pass time. The main change is that unlike Cookie Clicker or Candy Box, Hero of the Kingdom doesn‚Äôt run by itself and has a (mostly) definitive end, tapped together with what could almost be considered a story and some minor exploration.

Beginning on a secluded farm, you take up the mantle of the world‚Äôs premier errand boy, poking your nose into everybody‚Äôs business in the hopes they‚Äôll set you off on another menial task they couldn‚Äôt be bothered to do themselves.Hero of the Kingdom, in everything it does, is a personification of every tedious fetch quest you‚Äôve ever done in an RPG, stripped of everything but finding and delivering the item and then being patted on the head and told you‚Äôve done a great service to the kingdom.

I don‚Äôt think developer Lonely Troops had any doubts about what they were making though, and have deviously engineered the perfect loop of turning mundane tasks into accomplishments. Thanks are given for every small deed you perform, unimportant numbers are always going up, and the achievements pour out like candy letting you know no matter how simple the job, you did a damn fine job clicking your way through it!

And then before you know you‚Äôve constructed a profitable trading cycle, picked the country clean of mushrooms, and risen up in the ranks to where no one would dare refuse your prying questions. Hero of the Kingdom would almost feel nefarious if it didn‚Äôt have a clear ending, so adept is it at roping you in and making it feel as if the entire game isn‚Äôt just cleverly disguised busywork requiring no skill and barely any effort.

But for something that is fine letting you go after a few hours, I was fine indulging Hero of the Kingdom and its exploitation of a basic human need for self gratification. I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs a good game, but it‚Äôs an easy way to waste some time that won‚Äôt hold you hostage past the point of some mindless fun (for lack of a better word).

Maybe a farmer needs someone to go to town to sell his flour, so you get flour, click to switch screens to the town, and sell the flour to a merchant. reviewText:
At first glance your average gamer might dismiss Hero of the Kingdom as an oddity, a curious game with minimal feedback and graphics and could be considered a time-filler, a placeholder title to play in between longer and more involved gaming sessions. To do so would be a disservice to the gamer and to Hero of the Kingdom, as there is a lot more under the surface than what first appears, and through the course of a short story, you will become, the Hero of the Kingdom.

If you enjoy your gaming more casual, and less intense, Hero of the Kingdom definitely has a lot to offer. The game interface is simple and intuitive, and yet it is also never obtrusive. All gameplay is directed by mouse clicks. The action takes place on simple overhead maps, and your mouse clicks naturally will flow as the story and the gameplay layers on.

The complexity of Hero of the Kingdom comes in its economy and the use of selling items of value or to trade for items of usefullness. Should your character require to pass a bridge that is broken, they may need to sell unrequired items to obtain the help, rope and other necessities to move further on. You will gain skills such as fishing and hunting, with simple mouse clicks taking all guess work out of the equation. You either have the equipment to do the task, or you don't. There really is no challenge here.

This laid back notion is continued with the minimal music and sound effects. Both are equally pleasing, but ultimately forgettable. There is nothing about the game, from the gameplay, to the audio, that really stands out. It is all as inoffensive and flavorless as can be possible.

In many ways, Hero of the Kingdom feels like a slightly improved Facebook game, without the social interaction. Certainly the gameplay harkens back to that mindset, and without any kind of graphical flourish, could easily be mistaken as one. Where it succeeds is that it layers on additional systems through hunting, fishing and flower collecting, while telling a simple story about a long forgotten evil that is uniting various minion cliches in order to hunt down the good people of the kingdom.

Hero of the Kingdom is a fun diversion that requires so little of your attention and so little of the gamer that one could forget that they were actually playing a game here and not an interactive click-a-thon. There is enough gameplay here to recommend to the casual gamer but only to this subset of gamer might there be some enjoyment found.

Hero of the Kingdom is by no means a bad game, in fact, I rather enjoyed my short four hour journey. But there are a great many alternatives for your gaming dollar that demand more from the gamer, and the gamer should demand more from the creator. Hero of the Kingdom wouldn't be out of place being hosted for free on some website, perhaps with a banner ad - there just isn't enough gameplay to fully justify a purchase.

5/10.

Quaint like an elderly lady's bungalow filled with many past adventures and expeditions, the attractively detailed land in Hero of the Kingdom possesses the old-fashioned quest-orientated method of play that I have yearned for through many wishful Steam purchases but had yet to truly discover until now.

Hero of the Kingdom ranks highly in my gaming library as one of the most satisfyingly rewarding games I have played on Steam to date. It is most certainly one of the top 3 which I eagerly gave myself an auspicious pat on the back for buying. At $1.49 (75% off) it is money well spent. Completion only took me two days totalling 8 hours or so (didn't bother to quit game when taking dog for a walk). The game play is therapeutic and healing as even with a generic storyline, the long but seldom arduous line of quests are gratifyingly addictive. If you enjoy RPGs as I do and rarely skip side quests as it is half the fun, then I highly recommend this title.

The controls are as easy as can be and I can't honestly admit this is a strategy game as it does not give the player a chance at failure as you will see if you play it. It isn't a game to test your gaming skills but a chance to relax from more demanding games. Out of games you can use to relax and enjoy like you used to enjoy games as a child, it never feels like a waste of time or is uncomfortable to play in terms of time or effort of lack thereof.

reviewText:
Hero of the Kingdom is a pretty solid adventure/very light RPG hybrid. It's a bit odd to describe it, as the game wants to seem like an adventure but it comes out as something fairly unique. You start as a simple farm lad trying to find where your father went off to after bandits ransacked your farm, and end up being, as the title says, the hero of the entire kingdom.

To achieve this end result, you must click, and click, and click! This can be from anything as simple as delivering a letter from clickable person to clickable person #2 to defeating various armies of villainous foes by gathering troops and supplies. There's also objects in the background that, when clicked upon, give various items relating to what they are. These can be very helpful for trading for what you need or selling to get extra gold, though none of them are necessary typically and are just there to make the game last longer.

Speaking of length, it took me 3.3 hours to beat the game, including all my clicking of the extra objects (of which I got about 95%). I was somewhat annoyed to find that I couldn't go back and clean up the last few objects I needed once I had beaten it, but this will only affect you if you're a completionist or achievement hunter. If you are, just be wary of that.

The story is very basic of course, even just basing it on the summary I gave, but it's a quaint little adventure-sorta game. At $7 (and cheaper on sales presumably), this is a nice choice for an interesting game to check out.

reviewText:
Hero of the Kingdom is a neat little Point and Click game that combines the classic Hidden Object genre with some light RPG elements, quests and resource management. The game was developed by Lonely Troops, a Slovakian Indie studio consisting of 2 brothers.

STORY
Without going too much into detail, the story is pretty generic weak-boy-saves-the-world material. Bandits burn down your house and kidnap your father, so you set out on a quest to rescue him, find out what the bandits' motives are and put an end to all evil to make the kingdom a peaceful and safe place again. Add magic, ghosts, talking frogs, goblins and lizardmen to that and, well, there you go. Nothing spectacular or innovative there, but gameflow-wise it keeps the boat afloat, so that's at least something.

VISUALS
Graphically, the game may as well be from the 1990's era of simulation games such as Anno 1602 or Age of Empires, which isn't a bad thing at all. The enviroments have loads of details that you often only see at a second glance and it's quite cool to discover new things in areas that you have already visited many times. However, do note that the enviroments are absolutely static - they are basically drawings with quest/action markers on top of them, so you won't see cows eating grass, fishes swimming around or anything like that. The best you get is some minor animation effects for water and smoke, but that's about it. If anything changes in the enviroment like, say, a NPC is moving from A to B, he slowly fades out on A and then slowly fades in on B, so there aren't any actual animations for anything. While that's no deal-breaker for me personally, it surely would've been awesome if the game felt a bit more alive and actually more like a sim rather than a P'n'C game with rendered backgrounds.

GAMEPLAY
The game is basically a Hidden Object game where you can freely move around between the various locations to explore them and hunt, collect and harvest goods that you'll eventually need for quests, trades or tasks. All items that you gather will be put into your inventory and you decide whether you want to sell them for gold or trade them for other items that you might need for a certain quest.

All interactions such as hunting, fishing, harvesting or fighting cost resources in the form of knifes, arrows, bowls, fishing rods, swords, shields etc. and if you have a bow but no arrows, you can't go hunting. While the various tasks require various resources, all tasks require a certain amount of health points (similar to Action Points in turn-based games). They basically represent your stamina and if you have depleted your health, you can't finish any tasks until you replenish it again. This is easily done by taking a nap in a tent, camp or inn. The different resting places require different resources: while you need fruits or meat to sleep in a tent or a camp, you need hard gold to sleep in an inn. In return, you get rewarded with the most health points out of the 3 resting places because it's more restorative to sleep in an actual bed rather than in a tent, obviously.

Generally, managing your resources is an important part of the game as you need to think ahead and estimate whether you might need certain items later down the road. If you sell everything right away, you most definitely will have to re-purchase the items in order to complete tasks or quest. On the other hand, if you keep absolutely everything in your inventory, you might not be able to purchase required items that are only sold for gold - simply because you didn't earn any gold by selling stuff you do not need.

Other than that, it's basically back and forth tracking between the different locations to look out for new or updated quests and new activities, which often only spawn after certain quests are completed.

PLAYTIME & REPLAYABILITY
Beating the story took me roughly 5 hours, however, the largest chunk of playtime is dedicated to finding the large amount of hidden objects/resources and doing various tasks to gain even more resources. The actual story itself makes only a small piece of the pie.

For me personally, the game has only very little replayability. Once you've beaten it, you've beaten it. There's no real point or incentive to come back to it again, especially since it's easily doable to get 100% of the achiements in a single playthrough if you just take your time and don't rush from quest to quest.

CONCLUSION
Hero of the Kingdom isn't flawless, but the visual appeal, the relaxing atmosphere and the simple yet interesting gameplay makes this a decent game for a casual evening when you're not in the mood to shoot and kill things on the screen.

Somewhat like a TM game, but involves resources.

The mechanics are flawless, and the artwork is great.

It is a simple and clever game that moves a bit slowly for me, but I think it's worth a look. Might be just what you're looking for.

So I recommend giving the demo a go, at least.

reviewText:
Hero of the Kingdom is a medieval fantasy adventure game. After your farm gets burned down by bandits, you set out to find your father, helping people across the kingdom and becoming the adventurer you always dreamed of being.

Pros: This game is a light straightforward adventure. Each quest or encounter requires you to assemble a certain amount of money or equipment to accomplish. As you successfully accomplish goals, additional parts of the maps are revealed, allowing you to go to new location and get additional quests. You also advanced through three level of hunting, fishing and gathering skills, each stage revealing new resources on the map, giving you a reason to go back to locations you didn't need to access anymore.

Cons: The entire game is a linear adventure, save side quests. If you have the required items for a combat, you will win that combat, no action or strategy involved. The game is void of randomization: people are there where they're supposed to be, resources can be gathered once or twice and do not regenerate, enemies or hunting game don't respawn. There is no replay value to this game.

I came across this while trying to curb my game expenditure by trawling the depths of the cheapest games on steam and the fact this review (and many of the steem reviews) is positive reflects how cheap/bundled this game often is. It's a simple, short but quite well done little time-killer that might appeal when you are in the mood for something slower.

You progress through a series of reasonably pretty full-screen maps. Each one you visit might hold a handfull of missions plus perhaps a merchant, tradesman, somewhere to rest, etc and will definately hide a number of hidden objects to find. Once you unlocked each screen you can return at any time to use the merchants, finish side quests or pick up any hidden objects you missed.

The story is standard fantasy fare but is fine. The graphics are ok for a game so much about staring at the screen and set the mood well. The game play is good initially though starts to grate and grind a bit in the later stages even in a comparatively short game. For example consuming food at a camp is essential to gain heart points (used to perform most quests/activities) which is accompanied by a pretty but time consuming little 'nighty night' graphic sequence. Very atmospheric the first couple of times but you need loads of heart points to get through the game and end up spamming the camp sites.

It is a game that you cannot really lose - instead you just kind of amble through it... That said, I did finish it... And I did hunt about a bit for the hidden items before finishing the well-flagged final quest... And I paid ¬£0.69 for 5 hours gameplay... Overall that makes it hard not to recommend.

reviewText:
Short version: 85%Hero of the Kingdom mixes turn-based fantasy strategy gameplay with tycoon-like resource management on a strictly casual level. What is remarkable about it is the good balance between the gameplay aspects.

Long version:Hero of the Kingdom is a resource management strategy game‚Äì something that fits well to the portfolio of the Slovakian development team‚Äì with a fantasy adventure theme.

The goal is always to gather enough resources to pass the current objective. This requires a careful management of gold (for tools to gather the resources with) and strength (which serves the role of time units). There is no combat or levelling: if you have the resources to pass an obstacle, you automatically do so.
The mechanics are decent, but not perfect: there are exploits to get infinite gold and strength (although slowly), and it is easy to get confused by the variety of required resources by the end.

The story is fairly basic: find abducted relative, find bad sorcerer, kill bad sorcerer. This simplicity works to its advantage though as it lets the game put more focus on the dozens of side quests, giving it a classic RPG feel. Still, most players will likely reach 100% completion status within 4-5 hours, making Hero of the Kingdom a short, but fun game.

A nice, casual point-and-click adventure game with resource management and a decent storyline, Hero of the Kingdom is a nice game that fulfills it's purpose, with low-to-no pressure on the player to get things done fast. It's easy to play, even while distracted. And thus definitely well-suited to a casual player, or someone who wants to play a little something that's not-too-engaging with a little free time.

=Complete Review=  (TL:DR version and Conclusion at the bottom)

=The Story: 3/5= You play as a farm boy with dreams of grandeur, of who's father has left you to take care of the farm while he takes care of some errands in town. One day, while you're out repairing the old lookout tower down the road from the farm, bandits set your father's farm ablaze. Not even raiding it, just raizing the whole thing! Now with no home, you must set out on a quest to find your father, who has not returned, and find out why the bandits destroyed your home.

Throughout your adventure, you find many people in need of your aid. Some who also were hassled by the same bandits who burned your farm to the ground. And soon find that there are much bigger things at work than just the bandits.

The story is engaging enough to encourage playing it through to the end, but simple enough to allow players to take a break if need be, with no pressure or timers.

=The User Interface: 2/5=  The interface is barely there, which is nice for those who prefer a minimalistic UI. At each of the four corners of the screen, there are buttons to bring up the actual UI or to serve as a function of their own, of which they tuck themselves out of view when not moused over.

My only real complaint is how cluttered the inventory can get, but.. I figure one easy fix would be, I dunno... Cleaning it out?

... I've got a problem with playing pack rat, yes...

=The Gameplay: 3/5= The gameplay is pretty nice and simple. The layout is from a overhead view, and you click on what you want to interact with. Arrows at the edges of the screen indicate that you can move in that direction to another screen. Typically little icons will hover over things that need to be, or can be interacted with.
But, as you progress through the game, there's more things to interact with that aren't highlighted. Hidden objects of a sort, if you will. Of which result in some very nice resources in-game, and achievements if you find a lot of them.

=The Graphics: 3/5= The graphics are nice, sweet, and to the point. They're well done, and it's not often that there's sprites or the like that overly clash with the area. Everything blends well together, and doesn't have severe drops or increase in certain objects' quality, thus looking like they'd logically exist in the same setting.

=The Audio: 3/5=  The music serves it's purpose decently. The music is nice, without being overly repetitive, and matches the settings quite well. But it's also not the kind of music you'll be finding yourself listening to when not playing the game. The sound effects are nice, and also serve to give a idea on what's in the current scene. There's not much of this employed though, sadly. And I do hope that's addressed in the sequel.

=Complete Review=  (TL:DR version and Conclusion at the bottom)

=The Story: 3/5= You play as a farm boy with dreams of grandeur, of who's father has left you to take care of the farm while he takes care of some errands in town. One day, while you're out repairing the old lookout tower down the road from the farm, bandits set your father's farm ablaze. Not even raiding it, just raizing the whole thing! Now with no home, you must set out on a quest to find your father, who has not returned, and find out why the bandits destroyed your home.

Throughout your adventure, you find many people in need of your aid. Some who also were hassled by the same bandits who burned your farm to the ground. And soon find that there are much bigger things at work than just the bandits.

The story is engaging enough to encourage playing it through to the end, but simple enough to allow players to take a break if need be, with no pressure or timers.

At each of the four corners of the screen, there are buttons to bring up the actual UI or to serve as a function of their own, of which they tuck themselves out of view when not moused over.

My only real complaint is how cluttered the inventory can get, but.. I figure one easy fix would be, I dunno... Cleaning it out?

Arrows at the edges of the screen indicate that you can move in that direction to another screen. Typically little icons will hover over things that need to be, or can be interacted with.

Hero of the Kingdom is a slightly unusual mix of point-and-click adventure and rpg. It looks like an old-school isometric rpg, but there is no character to control - instead all actions are performed by clicking on object like in a point&click title. The basic rpg premise is still here (slight spoilers!) - an ordinary boy on a quest to find his father turns into a hero that saves the land from dire evil. Yeah, like no one expected that, spoilers over. The boy learns skills during the adventure - hunting, herbalism, etc - in order to get closer to his goal. As if the mix wasn't unusual enough the game adds in some Hiden Object elements - there are treasures and extra items hidden around in the bushes, rivers, barrels.

Visually the game has nothing to be shy of, it's a simple but well drawn style. Map elements are clearly distinguishible and even the hidden items are fairly easy to spot with a little practice. It's overall easy on the eye even for longer sessions. The audio is pleasant enough too, can't say much in detail about it personally but at least it feels right. Sadly, there is very little, if any, voice acting and that might diminish the enjoyment for some players - while lots of detailed text and dialogues can be enrich the world it might also bore the player.

Personally I find the mix pretty entertaining, then again I enjoy casual games so take what I say with a grain of salt. Nevertheless, the story moves at a good enough pace to keep boredom away and it's easy to enjoy this in bite-sized portions if so desired. Time-wise the game takes around 5 hours for a relaxed playthrough, dipping to maybe 3-3.5 for a speedy run and climbing to approx 8 for a single 100% run. At L5 that is pretty good value for anyone who likes a more casual adventure.

tl;dr: At ¬£5 it's a good mix of point&click, adventure, and casual gameplay.

Completed the game with 100% achievements.

About the gameBefore I say anything else, I'd like to point out that this IS a clicking game. Although it wasn't mentioned in the tags it kinda fits that genre very well. So if you don't like clicking don't get the game and save yourself from posting a rant.

The story starts with the life of a boy living a peaceful life in their farm. But, things starts to get chaotic when your father went missing and your house being burned down to nothing leaving you homeless. Now the boy must embark on a journey to find his missing father and find out the cause of the attack. You will be meeting different people from small villages along the way and experience the life of a traveler as you earn fame and make a name for yourself.

My thoughtsThe game is overall fun. It is mainly about resources management and will make yourself analyzing and thinking but not to the point of frustration. There will be plenty of items in-game:this includes item such as food, weapons, crafting materials, and more. Acquiring items are earned by either completing tasks given by the NPCs or bartering with merchants. This works by giving a certain item from your inventory in-exchange of another of the same value. Ofcourse, the game also has a currency which will be a necessity later on.

There's nothing much to say about the game except for the fact that if you're not into too much action and just want to sit down and play relaxing game yet entertaining then, you should give this a try.

--- This paragraph might contains minor spoilers. But, I'll put it here anyway for people who wants to know what to expect from the game. ---
The game starts with a realistic story of a young boy as stated above. But, things get weird when you suddenly need help of mages from the guild who *obviously* can use magic. You'll start getting items that is related to alchemy too and you will have to fight fantasy-ish creature not much like at the beginning where you only fend off wolves.

Now this may come a surprise to some people but it can be either looked at as positive and negative. I was expecting the game to be realistic until the end when the boy matures enough. Instead, it turned out that the entire plot of the story revolves around a certain wizard and it gets cliche from then on.

This is a casual Resource Management game.
I mean casual by both slow-paced and easy to beat.

The Good :
- Simple, Relaxing gameplay.

The Bad :
- Remember, this is NO RPG or STRATEGY. All about handling resources and clicking tiny hidden things.
- One playthrough's enough for all achievement. 3 hours for me to get them all.
- Management gets too easy once you found out a way to make money.
- You never know when you don't need tools anymore(Resource nodes will decay in one or two gathers, and are limited. But don't worry that you can BUY resources from NPCs)

- Bulk purchase option needed. It's tiresome to click hundred times when shopping.

6/10, Well worth the price, but not too great. And they're making the sequel so I'd like to play it as well.

reviewText:
I started Hero of the Kingdom without any idea of what it was going to be about. I bought it at a good sale price, the single screenshot I saw looked nice, and I don't like to spoil myself with trailers or large numbers of screenshots going into a game. I was immediately put off, thinking that it was going to be an extremely boring hand-holding hidden object adventure. I'm not fond of hidden object games in general, and I hadn't really been expecting to play one when I started.

I wasn't actually wrong in my initial impression--Hero of the Kingdom is a really user-friendly point and click adventure with hidden object elements. The thing about this game, though, is that it is the best casual point and click adventure. The game is beautiful, the music is both relaxing and adventurous (and a true pleasure to listen to), and the sound effects feel crisp and fit just right. Tons of polish all around, and you can tell that there was a lot of love put into making this game.

Don't go in expecting to find a particularly detailed story, but what is there is enjoyable as well. Again, very simple, but it feels right. This is a game you can enjoy in small pieces, or devour all at once for a relaxing evening. Sometimes it's nice to play something simple and pleasant.

Also, the main character solving a lot of problems by being a pretty decent carpenter was oddly refreshing. It's a skill that doesn't really get a lot of serious recognition even in crafting types of games, and it's handled so reasonably and practically within the confines of the story that I couldn't help but smile at moments like finishing construction of the water mill.

reviewText:
Hero of the Kingdom is a short point-and-click adventure in a fantasy setting.  The player begins as a farmboy and goes on an adventure by essentially completing errands by interacting with various hotspots on a beautifully drawn map.  More screens are unlocked as one progresses through the story.  In addition to the main story, there are various hidden objects such as mushrooms or lost crates scattered throughout the game world.  These objects blend in well enough that they are not all immediately spotted, but if you should choose to find them all, it's by no means a pixel hunt.

Someone looking for an extremely non-challenging and casual gaming experience may enjoy this title.  In fact, I somewhat enjoyed it as something to do while watching television.

However, I am unable to recommend this game because of its incredibly short length.  I was able to 100% the game in about four hours. Most of those four hours were spent backtracking.  For instance, while fishing, you may run out of energy.  You must then backtrack to the inn to rest.  You then return to the lake to continue fishing, and you run out of bait.  You must then backtrack to purchase more bait.  And then your rod breaks.  You get the idea.

In short, Hero of the Kingdom is not all bad by any means.  It's a decent little game that looks and sounds good, even if it is simplistic.  However, the writing is not so hot.  Unless you are absolutely in love with the genre, there's almost certainly better and more fulfilling ways of spending your time.

For me, as well as many other reviewers (so it seems) this game was a nice unexpected pleasent surprise.
I actually went into game expecting a completely different genre - I thaught it would be a casual town building/management game, what it actually was is nice blend of P&C adventure with nice gamey RPG elements and statistics, and some hidden object elements.
While playing it on a small(ish) laptop screen (1366x768) the graphics were nice crisp 2D painting-like pictures reminescent of those detailed, colorful and clear-lined screens of games like Desperados, Commandos, Settlers and in modern times Anno series. This one though is fully in 2d, which I personally like a lot, cause it still manages to deliver more slick, more detailed and thin-lined drawings, opposed to 3d muddying of features caused by texture requirements and antialiasing. I'd argue that 3d engines still aren't capable of producing such fine lines as simple and clear as 2d drawing/sprite and this game uses that fact to the full effect. The visual presentation is, again, clear, colorful and full of small details.
So far I'd played for some 2 or 3 hours (ignore the Steam stats, I don't understand why it didn't record the last session) in one sitting and the experience was delightful, the flow of quests and tasks slick and satisfying and gameplay varied enough to still feel interesting, though in the beginning you solely click on few points on screen and manage few basic stats like food and building materials. Slowly you get involved with you character, though his actions aren't described in much verbouse prose, but later when he manageas to learn few skills and has some successful quests uder his belt you do start to care and do notice when he starts calling some officer HIS captain, since he recently enlisted in land's military. The progres from a naive farmboy to adventurer to ultimate hero is a familiar tale, but it's nicely done and somewhat beliveably depicted - in slow careful stages. In this case journey is more satisfying than the end and slow exploring of map, solving quests and leveling up" (though the only stat connected to that is reputation) makes a nice calm romp.
So my overal oppinion is that it's competent and surprizingly fun casual P&C adventure. It has earned my recommendation fair and square

This casual point-and-click game is difficult for me to recommend mostly in part due to the extensive annoyance of every task you perform being a fetch quest. The fact it is extremely linear with very few options in terms of how you complete a quest only exacerbates matters. Either you harvest certain supplies you need, or outright buy them. I expect a certain simplicity with casual games like this, but this seemed to be a bit much in that regard. The story is very minimalistic with writing on par with a young children's story--just enough to make a point. It has very pleasing visuals and sound and the game length felt just about right from a completionist viewpoint.

That said, this is a game that would be delightful to play with children. The simple story, hidden-object elements, and resource management just feel like it targets more of a family video-game night and I am reminded of old adventure classics like Mixed Up Mother Goose I would play with my parents and friends when I was young.

Other players looking for a light, relaxing gaming experience can just sit down and enjoy the story without any pressures or puzzling to do however, players wanting a game that provides a more thoughtful experience may end up disappointed.

The gimmick is interesting, in which you simply have to find and collect items, remembering where to barter and trade goods for the best prices in order to build up a supply train that enables you to progress. But at the mid-game, once you join the army, the game starts to get repetitive, consisting of nothing more than farming and exploiting existing chains, rather than actually discovering anything new. I'd have liked to see more side-missions, the ones that aren't always marked on the map and which require hidden-object skills, or to have had more complex trading objectives that required you to make better use of the map. That said, still a fun game worth experiencing.

Hero of the Kingdom was not the game I was expecting. When looking at the screen shots I got the impression this was going to be a medieval RTS similar to Strongholds, but more casual. I was wrong, but it turned out to be a good thing.

Hero of the Kingdom is a click your own adventure game. You start out as a never described boy that must make his way through an epic journey to save his father and ultimately the entire kingdom. You play within a static background and must click on various elements to get loot and proceed to other static screens. There are lite crafting elements. You get herbs and wheat and must turn these into goods for profit or to further the story. The quests are not linear. Yes there are some story quests you must complete to proceed, but not all the quests are that way. In terms of quests I would say there are roughly 20 to 30. I would say the average gamer would beat this in 4 hours, but total play time should not exceed 6.

The story is mediocre, the writing is actually kind of silly, (reads like it was written by a teenager) the amount of clicking is ridiculous, there's no challenge to the game, there's even a hint button that will literally tell you exactly what to do to proceed. Honestly, this game is well suited for young teens and children more so than adults. However, there was just enough fun from all the clicking, crafting, and reading that I didn't mind finishing the game. Actually, I finished the game, realized I hadn't got all the achievements and played it all over again!

Bottom line: This game is not for adults, but it's fun enough to keep you playing till the end. I only paid $3 for it and the experience was well worth the cash.

This casual point-and-click game is difficult for me to recommend mostly in part due to the extensive annoyance of every task you perform being a fetch quest. The fact it is extremely linear with very few options in terms of how you complete a quest only exacerbates matters. Either you harvest certain supplies you need, or outright buy them. I expect a certain simplicity with casual games like this, but this seemed to be a bit much in that regard. The story is very minimalistic with writing on par with a young children's story--just enough to make a point. It has very pleasing visuals and sound and the game length felt just about right from a completionist viewpoint.

That said, this is a game that would be delightful to play with children. The simple story, hidden-object elements, and resource management just feel like it targets more of a family video-game night and I am reminded of old adventure classics like Mixed Up Mother Goose I would play with my parents and friends when I was young.

Other players looking for a light, relaxing gaming experience can just sit down and enjoy the story without any pressures or puzzling to do however, players wanting a game that provides a more thoughtful experience may end up disappointed.

The gimmick is interesting, in which you simply have to find and collect items, remembering where to barter and trade goods for the best prices in order to build up a supply train that enables you to progress. But at the mid-game, once you join the army, the game starts to get repetitive, consisting of nothing more than farming and exploiting existing chains, rather than actually discovering anything new. I'd have liked to see more side-missions, the ones that aren't always marked on the map and which require hidden-object skills, or to have had more complex trading objectives that required you to make better use of the map. That said, still a fun game worth experiencing.

I wasn't expecting too much from this game when I started out. There is something very minimalist about the user interface and moving about the world that I quickly found rather appealing, though. The game is very well balanced in how you gain new skills, the things you can find, the quests you can solve, and though not strictly speaking linear, there is a rough order in which things need to be done.

There was something refreshing in how you move through the world not as a fully-fleshed 3D or even 2D character, but by clicking on the buildings, people and items you wish to interact with, clicking on direction arrows on the edges of an area to move instantly to the next one. For adventure games requiring a bit of walking back and forth, and strange as it was to start with, this makes it less boring as many other games as there is no transit time to speak of to get around.

It makes for a nice game in between other more time-consuming games. With a playthrough time of 3-4 hours if you wish to do everything you can, find all you can, craft all you can, hunt all you can - not strictly speaking necessary, but there is something satisfying about making as much money as possible too.

The story is fine, the hidden-object aspect of the game for finding treasure, mushrooms, eggs, etc is nicely done, and even the unconventional combat system, if you can call it that, where you gather the resources you need to win a given battle and return to the location of it with the weapons, manpower and potions needed to overcome the enemy is an interesting and refreshing twist on what you'd expect to see in a game like this.

I think I bought this very cheaply in a bundle, but even at its regular price, I'd still feel I got a few hours of entertaining gameplay's worth for my money, and cheaper than spending a similar time in the cinema, which is how I often calculate entertainment value when it comes to computer games.

One of the hints I was given at some point consisted of doing tasks for people, which would have been all well and good, if it weren't for the fact that pretty much every single task required some sort of payment up front.  Occasionally, you'll get a somewhat sizable-seeming sum, but since everything is so expensive, it'll probably be gone very quickly. So if you need that stuff later, as I did, you'll be buying them from the store.

So glad to finally play a casual game on PC that isn't a mobile port. I would characterize Hero of the Kingdom as a casual adventure game with some trading elements. There are no reflexes required, you simply need to click around the different maps to collect various items and turn them in to complete tasks. When you complete most tasks you beat the game. Overall you shouldn't expect to play this for more than a couple hours but it is a good use of time where you don't need to stress out. I found the story to be serviceable given the scale of the game.

All actions in the game are ultimately governed by its currency, which is gold. So if you want to do lots of things, such as stock up on supplies, get more hit points or hire more helpers, you need gold. This is where the trading part of the game comes in. There is only a finite number of resources you can gather before you run out, but you can manufacture more money by astutely trading the resources between various NPCs. I found this to be kind of interesting, but ultimately maybe not that constructive as the game actually gives you a good amount of money. I blame it on my RPG hoarding tendencies, but if you sell everything you gather (and you should! there are no missables!) you should only have to do a minimum of trade farming.

Lastly, many people play this game because it is easy to get 100% achievements. Not really my thing, but that could be a reason to play this game as well.

I'm really not sure about reviews that call this a 'clicker' game of the Clicker Heroes/Adventure Capitalist ilk. This is nothing like those. Yes, fundamentally, you just click. But that's true of Monkey Island and Minesweeper, and no one would call those clickers.

Now that I've got that off of my chest, time for the real review. This game borrows heavily from 90's D&D-based CRPGs. It's got the same visual style, and the same sort of subquests, gathering, improving skills and back-and-forth. But it doesn't have any of the D&D elements of those games. You're not roleplaying, managing your inventory or obsessing over stats. It's a simple, quick, fun waste of time. And sometimes, those are just what you want.

I wouldn't pay full price for it, but see it on sale or in a bundle? Snap it up.

Though it is a short game, nevertheless, it has an interesting story, and even one that can be called emotional. Pretty simplistic in nature, yet I found myself having fun at the little things and, contrary to other games, being a more mundane hero than it is expected.

Just finished it in 5 hours, so for total game time, I'd say that's pretty much the time it takes to finish the game, and all the achievements.

That being said, shows a bit of replayability value. there isn't much to do once you're done. completely. Finish the last achievements, find some more mushrooms, sleep with meat a few more times, and trade until you have 5000 gold in total.
But, it's like finishing a pokemon game completely. Finding all the pokemon, and levelling them to the max. Restarting the game from scratch seems like a waste to the time it took, and the story/adventure won't change much.

Graphic wise, it's quite good. Not too new of a graphics, but how all areas have small hidden things, like hidden pearls, and mushrooms in them (that you sometimes unlock by becoming a better herbalist) makes each area new, and abundant!

The story itself isn't too impressive. but it's fun, and not only can you quite often start doing side quests, and unlock special areas, you can also continue the story, and 2 screens further, another small bit of story is available, so almost all screens have a special story part. This means it's easily focussable on the next challenge, and you won't get lost in the quests and finding the solutions.

Gameplay: Gameplay in this game is what really drives the game itself forward. A lot of items that are clickable do not have an actually specific picture, like the trader, or a quest giver does. Sometimes, it's just a simple mushroom in the middle of a forest, that you can click. This means sometimes, boredly looking around actually rewards you. The actual movements aren't great, but it's kind of fun to see soldiers changing position, a few arrows all pointing towards a single enemy, and then moving on. Also, even though you're probably the same size as a normal npc in the game, the fact that you don't see yourself on screen kind of helps the immersion. YOU are the one that checks out the little clearing in the forest, to see if you can help save the lumberjack, and you are the one that decides to attack the boar. Strangely enough, if you would be a few pixels on the screen, you'd be too small to matter, but now, you really do.

Basically, I recommend it. I think since it's not too high in replayability, it's probably better to wait for a sale, but there's no definitive need for it. It's just a fun little game, that you can enjoy, until you're completely done.

While this game is no RPG at all, it is worth the buy on sale. Full price is not really a fair buy, as the game is really short (I got all the achievements) and has no replay value at all.

It is essentially a casual clicker game with some hidden object dimension in it (more below). You go on from map to map, gathering food, objects, speaking to uninteresting NPCs, and accomplishing some dull quests for them. Yet, the game is catchy, and you can finish it in a row as it keeps being entertaining. You cannot die nor make mistakes, it is pretty easy, but it's fun.

To make some more money (necessary for quests) you can grab some objects hidden on the maps, such as mushrooms, fishes, crevices, eggs, and you can hunt animals. Strangely enough, becoming the Hero of the Kingdom also means plundering it from all its natural resources. This hidden dimension is nice as the objects have not been put randomly: eggs can be found in the forest or on cliffs, mushrooms are found near the woods. Everything makes sense.

The story has no interest at all. They could hardly have done a less interesting one. Too bad as it would have make the game better.

Finally, the late game is tedious. You have to fish everything and hunt every animals, so you need energy and you spend most of your time sleeping. Repetitive fights (where a fight means gathering enough potions trhgouh trade and then automatically resolve it for a guaranteed win) are just utterly boring. Without the pleasure of discovering new areas as all the bad guys are found in already visited places, it looses all interest.


Conclusion: A good game to buy on sale and spent a relaxing and entertaining yet too short time.
